content: The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" includes sections on improving policies related to advance directives, Medicare coverage for end-of-life planning consultations, a national information hotline for end-of-life decision-making, and increasing awareness of end-of-life planning. It also preempts any State law that prohibits health care treatment authorized by advance directives, while allowing for greater portability and deference to a patient's wishes. Medicaid regulations are also amended to require advance directives to be prominently placed in an individual's current medical record. The provisions of this paragraph preempt any State law inconsistent with them but do not preempt laws providing greater portability or deference to a patient's wishes. The effective dates for the amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) apply to provider agreements under title XVIII of the Social Security Act and State plans under title XIX, specified by the Secretary of Health and Human Services within 1 year of the Act's enactment. The Act extends the effective date for state law amendments under title XIX of the Social Security Act, allowing states time to meet additional requirements without penalty. In the case of a State with a 2-year legislative session, each year is considered a separate regular session of the State legislature. Medicare coverage for end-of-life planning consultation during initial preventive physical examination. Medicare now covers end-of-life planning consultations, which involve discussions between physicians and individuals about preparing advance directives, situations where they may be needed, and the benefits of developing a comprehensive end-of-life plan. The end-of-life plan should be updated periodically as health changes, identify resources for state requirements, including surrogate decision maker designation, and ensure physician willingness to follow advance directive wishes. Effective January 1, 2009, Medicare covers these consultations. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish a national information hotline for end-of-life decision-making and hospice care, providing consumer information about advance directives, end-of-life services, and hospice care. SEC. 5. INCREASING AWARENESS OF END-OF-LIFE PLANNING: Title III of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include a new part focused on programs to raise awareness of advance directive planning issues, including an initiative for advance directive education campaigns. The Secretary will conduct a national public education campaign to raise awareness about planning for care near the end of life, explain the importance of advance directives, and educate the public about hospice and palliative care. Grants will be used to support this campaign. The Secretary will use 60% of the appropriated funds for grants to public or nonprofit entities for a 3-year education campaign. $25,000,000 is authorized for this purpose.
